name: The Device Mesh
description: An expanding set of endpoints people use to access applications and information, or interact with people, social communities, governments, and businesses, forming a 'mesh' of connected devices.
accuracyNote: Device ecosystems grew but as walled gardens (Apple, Google, Samsung), not the open 'mesh' of interconnected devices described. The mechanism (vendor lock-in ecosystems vs. mesh interoperability) was wrong.

name: Ambient User Experience
description: User experiences would flow across the device mesh, creating a continuous and ambient experience that blends physical, virtual, and electronic environments.
accuracyNote: Partially realized — Apple's Continuity, Handoff, and Universal Clipboard showed this vision, but truly seamless ambient UX remains a work in progress.

name: 3D Printing Materials
description: Advances in 3D printing materials (metals, biocompatible, carbon fiber, glass, electronics) would expand use cases dramatically.
accuracyNote: Mixed — material diversity did expand significantly for industrial use (metal printing for aerospace, bioprinting), but the broader transformation was slower than predicted.

name: Information of Everything
description: Everything in the digital mesh produces, uses, and transmits information. Organizations must find ways to link data from all these sources.
accuracyNote: Accurate — the data explosion happened. Data lakes, data mesh architectures, and data integration platforms became essential enterprise infrastructure.

name: Advanced Machine Learning
description: Deep neural networks would move beyond classical computing to systems that can learn autonomously and act on what they learn. Prediction: this would create smart machines.
accuracyNote: Gartner correctly identified that deep neural networks would be transformative. However, the specific mechanism they described (systems that 'learn autonomously and act') didn't match reality — the transformer architecture and scaling laws that actually drove the revolution weren't anticipated. Credit for identifying the right area, but the path was different.

name: Autonomous Agents and Things
description: Smart machines including robots, autonomous vehicles, virtual personal assistants, and smart advisors would operate with increasing autonomy.
accuracyNote: The prediction described robots, autonomous vehicles, and smart advisors operating with increasing autonomy. Autonomous vehicles and physical robots largely failed to deliver. The 'AI agents' that emerged in 2024-2025 are LLM-based software agents — a fundamentally different concept than the physical autonomous things Gartner envisioned. The name matches; the reality doesn't.

name: Adaptive Security Architecture
description: Traditional security approaches would be inadequate. Organizations would need adaptive, multilayered security that responds in real time to threats.
accuracyNote: Zero trust and adaptive security are real, but 'traditional security would be inadequate' is something every security vendor had been saying for decades. Directionally correct but not a bold or specific prediction.

name: Advanced System Architecture
description: Neuromorphic computing, GPU-accelerated computing, and FPGAs would create new computing architectures optimized for specific workloads like AI.
accuracyNote: Highlighted neuromorphic computing, GPUs, and FPGAs. Neuromorphic went nowhere, FPGAs for AI didn't take off — GPUs won decisively. Only the GPU part was right, and that was already underway by 2016.

name: Mesh App and Service Architecture
description: Apps would be composed of loosely coupled microservices connected through APIs, enabling flexible, scalable architectures.
accuracyNote: Microservices and API-first design became popular, but this was already happening (SOA existed for years). More observation than prediction. Many organizations have since moved back toward modular monoliths.

name: IoT Architecture and Platforms
description: IoT platforms would emerge as the foundation for managing billions of connected devices, with standardized architectures and protocols.
accuracyNote: Mixed — AWS IoT, Azure IoT Hub, and Google Cloud IoT emerged, but the 'billions of devices' timeline was optimistic and standardization remains incomplete.
